title: 114_hr2003
content: The Act is titled the "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" and pertains to the distribution of death information by the Social Security Administration. The "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" amends Section 205(r) of the Social Security Act to require the Commissioner of Social Security to transmit information on deceased individuals to ensure completeness, timeliness, and accuracy. The Commissioner of Social Security will provide information on deceased individuals for use by federal and state agencies administering benefits, with safeguards in place to protect the information from unauthorized use. The agency operating the Do Not Pay system ensures proper payment of benefits through a cooperative arrangement with the agency's Inspector General, including reimbursement for costs associated with collecting information on deceased individuals. The Commissioner of Social Security may provide information on deceased individuals to federal agencies for specific purposes, as long as it does not conflict with their duties. This information sharing is done through a cooperative arrangement to ensure proper use of the data. The Commissioner of Social Security can share death information with federal agencies for specific purposes through a cooperative arrangement, allowing agencies to compare and disclose this information as needed. The Commissioner of Social Security can share death information with federal agencies for specific purposes such as proper payments, tax administration, debt collection, and policing functions. The Commissioner of Social Security can share deceased individuals' information with federal policing agencies for crime prevention, detection, and investigation purposes. Additionally, similar arrangements can be made with States for various specified purposes. The Commissioner of Social Security can utilize information on deceased individuals for authorized purposes, with appropriate safeguards in place. The Commissioner of Social Security can use safeguards to protect information for statistical and research purposes by Federal and State agencies. The term 'statistical purposes' is defined in the Confidential Information Protection and Statistical Efficiency Act of 2002. The amendments made to paragraphs (3), (4), (5), and (8) of section 205(r) of the Social Security Act will be repealed five years after the enactment of this Act. Additionally, section 6103(d)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be amended. Section 6103(d)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to replace "Secretary of Health and Human Services" with "Commissioner of Social Security" in subparagraphs (A) and (B), and to specify that information provided under the contract is only to be used by the Social Security Administration. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data for use by Federal agencies, including State agencies, as authorized by the Social Security Act. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data, including State agencies, for use by Federal agencies. The review will assess the accuracy, completeness, interoperability, accessibility, cost, security, and reliability of the data, as well as compare potential alternate sources. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data for Federal agencies, assessing accuracy, completeness, interoperability, accessibility, cost, security, and reliability. A report with recommendations will be submitted to Congress within 4 years of the Act's enactment. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will provide a recommendation on extending agency access to death data from the Commissioner of Social Security beyond the specified date. SEC. 7 of the Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012 is amended to improve the use of death data by government agencies. The Office of Management and Budget will issue guidance to agencies on maintaining databases of beneficiary information within 6 months of the enactment of this section. The Office of Management and Budget will provide agencies with access to death databases within 6 months of enactment to improve data matching for beneficiary information. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will develop a plan within 1 year to assist states, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations in providing death records electronically to the Federal Government. Government records related to the death of individuals may include recommendations to Congress for statutory changes or financial assistance to ensure electronic provision of such records by States, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations. Recommendations for funding may also be included in the plan. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with relevant agencies, will submit a plan to Congress within 270 days to improve data matching for benefits programs provided by States, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations. Tribal organizations offering federally funded benefits will enhance data matching with the Federal Government regarding the death of benefit recipients. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit annual reports to Congress on the implementation of this section, including recommendations. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit annual reports to Congress on the implementation of this section, including recommendations. Definitions for 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' are provided in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. SEC. 4. PLAN FOR ENSURING ACCURACY AND COMPLETENESS OF DEATH DATA BY SOCIAL SECURITY ADMINISTRATION. The Commissioner of Social Security, in consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, must submit a plan to Congress within 90 days of the enactment of this Act. The plan aims to ensure the accuracy and completeness of death data maintained by the Social Security Administration, including data on individuals not receiving benefits under titles II or XVI of the Social Security Act. The plan must include a procedure for identifying extremely elderly individuals. The plan required by the Social Security Administration must include procedures for identifying extremely elderly individuals who are still alive and improving policies for correcting erroneous records. This includes identifying individuals listed as dead who are actually alive and vice versa. The plan requires the Social Security Administration to improve procedures for identifying errors in records, including identifying alive individuals listed as dead and vice versa, and implementing statistical analysis to estimate the number of erroneous records. The Social Security Administration will implement a plan to improve record accuracy, including identifying errors in death data and estimating the number of erroneous records. Legislation recommendations will be made, and the plan must be implemented within 2 years of the Act's enactment.
